dataIdInfo.envirDesc: Microsoft Windows 7 Version 6.1 (Build 7601) Service Pack 1; Esri ArcGIS 10.2.1.3497

idCitation.resTitle: Community Water Systems Used in Drinking Water Indicator for CalEnviroScreen 2.0

dataIdInfo.idPurp:
The Office of Environmental Health Hazard Assessment (OEHHA) used community water system service boundaries as a part of the methodology to create the drinking water indicator in CalEnviroScreen 2.0 (October 2014). The drinking water indicator is one of several measures of pollution burden that is used in the calculation of overall CalEnviroScreen scores.
Community water systems were used in the development of the indicator. Community water systems are public water systems that serve at least 15 service connections used by yearlong residents or regularly serve at least 25 yearlong residents of the area served by the system, according to the California Safe Drinking Water Act. Many California water system service area boundaries are publicly available through the California Environmental Heath Tracking Program’s Water Boundary Tool (WBT). At the time of the development of the drinking water indicator, approximately half of California’s community water system service area boundaries were available. In order to have a complete set of boundaries, OEHHA approximated the remaining service area boundaries based on the locations of water quality sampling and the population served by each system.
OEHHA obtained water quality sampling locations through a confidentially agreement with the California Department of Public Health’s Division of Drinking Water (now part of the State Water Resources Control Board). Concerns regarding threats to water security are cited in the agreement. Since OEHHA’s approximated system boundaries are based on these confidential sampling locations, OEHHA cannot make them publicly available. However, by the agreement, these locations may be “displayed or represented in a manner that is randomized within a one-mile radius.” So here OEHHA is making available the location of the approximated water systems as points that were created randomly within an area defined as one mile beyond the approximated service boundary. For consistency, the publicly available water system boundaries extracted from the WBT are also made available here as points that represent the geographic center of the boundary. (To download the latest version of the Water Boundary Tool, please visit the California Environmental Health Tracking Program's website: http://www.ehib.org/page.jsp?page_key=762.)
dataIdInfo.idAbs:
This geodatabase contains a feature class, a file that contains a set of uniform point features that represent all community water systems used in the drinking water indicator. This information can be used to understand the approximate locations of water systems used in the creation of the CalEnviroScreen drinking water indicator.

This feature class contains 2,980 community water systems represented as points. OEHHA created a point located in the geographic center of 1,585 water system boundaries extracted from the WBT. For the remaining 1,395 systems not contained in the WBT, OEHHA created a random point representing each water system within an area defined as a one mile buffer beyond the approximated service boundaries to protect confidentiality.

The field “BoundarySo” in the feature class attribute table indicates whether the point comes from a system boundary extracted from the WBT or approximated by OEHHA.

enttyp.enttypd: Point feature class that represents community water systems
enttyp.enttypds: California Environmental Heath Tracking Program and the Office of Environmental Health Hazard Assessment
